Award.AwardTitle: Research Term on Real Harmonic Analysis and Its Applications to Partial Differential Equations and Geometric Measure Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Research Term on Real Harmonic Analysis and its Applications to Partial Differential Equations and Geometric Measure Theory" that will be held May 7-June 8, 2018 at the 2018, at Instituto de Ciencias Matematicas in Madrid, Spain.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of Harmonic Analysis, Geometric Measure Theory, and Partial Differential Equations. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at:

https://www.icmat.es/RT/2018/HAPDEGMT/index.php

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

Performance_Institution.Name: Universiy of Minnesota, School of Mathematics

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first goal of this conference, which has been a great success, was to create an environment to showcase recent breakthroughs in the areas of Harmonic Analysis, Partial Differential Equations (PDE), and Geometric Measure Theory (GMT) and to foster the new directions of research in these areas with a particular emphasis on their interaction. The conference involved a diverse collection of mathematicians stimulating innovation and new collaborations. It featured three mini-courses designed to engage graduate students and postdocs and an intensive workshop including, in particular, young mathematicians. The main research focus could be roughly described as an adaptation of Modern (Calder\'on-Zygmund-Stein) Harmonic Analysis to extremely general settings in an effort to study questions related to elliptic and parabolic PDE and GMT. The NSF grant supported 20 participants, most of them junior, 5 of them female, and has led to countless projects and many new collaborations. See the Final Report for details.

 

The list of researchers whose travel has been supported by the present grant is: 

The NSF grant supported the following researchers (f stands for female):  

Murat Akman

Jonatan Barreiro Bastos

Li Chen

David Cruz-Uribe

Zanbing Dai

Max Engelstein

Joseph Feneuil

John Garnett

Alyssa Genschaw (f)

Ben Jaye

Jose Luis Luna Garcia

Svitlana Mayboroda (f)

Tomas Merchan

Dario Mena

Irina Mitrea (f)

Lisa Naples (f)

Bruno Poggi Cevallos

Tatiana Toro (f)

Ignacio Uriarte-Tuero
